question:
Consider the linear applications 

$\begin{array}{cccc}
F: & \mathbb{R}^3 & \rightarrow  & \mathbb{R}^2 \\
  & (x, y, z) & \longrightarrow & (y, x-z)
\end{array}$
$\begin{array}{cccc}
G: & \mathbb{R}^2 & \rightarrow  & \mathbb{R}^2 \\
  & (x, y) & \longrightarrow & (x+y, x-2y)
\end{array}$

Choose the right answer:
answer1: $(G\circ F)(x, y, z)=(x+y-z, -2x+y+2z)$ and $(F\circ G)$ does not exist
answer2: $(F\circ G)(x, y, z)=(x+y-z, -2x+y+2z)$and $(G\circ F)$ does not exist
answer3: $(G\circ F)(x, y, z)=(F\circ G)(x, y, z)=(x+y-z, -2x+y+2z)$
answer4: $(G\circ F)(y, x-z)=(x+y-z, -2x+y+2z)$ and $(F\circ G)(x, y)=(x+y, x-2y)$

The Childfair Company has three plants producing child push chairs that are to be shipped to four distribution centers. Plants $1$, $2$, and $3$ produce $12$, $17$, and $11$ shipments per month, respectively. Each distribution center needs to receive $10$ shipments per month. The distance (in miles) from each plant ($i$) to the respective distributing centers ($j$) is given below:

\[
\begin{array}{c|c|c|c|c}
\text{Plant Dist. Center} & \text{1} & \text{2} & \text{3}  & \text{4}  \\
\text{1} & 800  & 1300 &  400 & 700\\
\text{2} & 1100 & 1400 &  600 & 1000 \\
\text{3} & 600  & 1200 &  800 & 900\\
\end{array}
\]	

The freight cost for each shipment is $100.50?$ per mile. Use the transportation simplex method to determine how much should be shipped from each plant to each of the distribution centers each month, to minimize the total shipping cost. question: Conclude about the existence of local maxima, local minima, and saddle points of $f\left(x,y\right)=xy-x^3-y^2$.

question:
A distribution company owns two warehouses (i) in the south of the country (W1 and W2). From these points, the company needs to supply its customers (j) in four cities, C1, C2, C3  and C4 (one customer per city). The transport cost for each tonne of material is 100 u.m./km. The following table shows the distances to be traveled between the two warehouses and the various cities (in km):

	\[
\begin{array}{l|cccc|}
& C_1 & C_2 & C_3  &  C_4\\
\hline
W_1 & 100 & 85 & 270  & 500 \\
W_2 & -  & 185 & 185 & 150\\
\hline
\end{array}
\]	

The requirements of customers C1, C2, C3 and C4 are respectively 200, 250, 400 and 150 tonnes. The inventory in both warehouses W1 and W2 is 200 and 500 tonnes, respectively. The company has established agreements with the various customers, setting the following prices to charge (u.m./ton):

	\[
\begin{array}{l|cccc|}
& C_1 & C_2 & C_3  &  C_4\\
\hline
W_1 & 10500  & 9250 & 27570  & 50870\\
W_2 & - & 19150 & 18600 & 15220\\
\hline
\end{array}
\]	

Determine the optimal solution, formulating a transport problem.

answer1: The line $r$ has the direction of the vector $w=(1, -3, -7)$.
answer2: The line $r$ has the direction of the vector $v=(1, 3, -1)$.

The Omega Manufacturing Company has discontinued the production of a certain unprofitable product line. This act created considerable excess production capacity. Management is considering devoting this excess capacity to one or more of three products; call them products 1, 2, and 3. The available capacity on the machines that might limit output is summarized in the following table:
	
	\[\begin{array}{|c|c|}
	\hline
	\text{Machine Type} & \text{Available Time (machine hours per week)} \\
	\hline
	\text{Milling machine} & 500 \\
	\text{Lathe} & 350 \\
	\text{Grinder} & 150 \\
	\hline
	\end{array}\]
		
The number of machine hours required for each unit for a given product is the following:
	
	\[\begin{array}{|l|c|c|c|}
	\hline
	\text{Machine Type} & \text{Product 1} & \text{Product 2} & \text{Product 3} \\
	\hline
	\text{Milling machine} & 9 & 3 & 5 \\
	\text{Lathe} & 5 & 4 & 0 \\
	\text{Grinder} & 3 & 0 & 2 \\
	\hline
	\end{array}\]
	
	The sales department indicates that the sales potential for products 1 and 2 exceeds the maximum production rate and the sales potential for product 3 is 20 units per week. The unit profit would be 50?, 20?, and 25? for products 1, 2, and 3, respectively. The objective is to determine how much of each product the company should produce to maximize the profit. Use a computer (Solver Add-in in Excel) to solve this model by the simplex method, considering that $x_{i}$ is the number of units of product $i~(i = 1~to~3)$ produced.

Find the solutions of the following linear system:
$$\begin{cases}
-x & + & y & + & z & = & 1 \\
 & & y & + & 3z & = & 2 \\
x &  &  & + & z & = & 1
\end{cases}$$
answer1: The system has $\left(1,\,2,\,0\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer3: The system has an infinite number of solutions, which are of the form $\left(0,\,y,\,\frac{y}{2}\right)$ for every $y\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer4: The system has $\left(0,\,-2,\,-1\right)$ as its unique solution.

Find the solutions of the following linear system:
$$\begin{cases}
x & - & y & + & 2z & - & 3t & = & 1 \\ 
2x & + & y & - & 2z & - & t & = & 2 \\ 
x &- &3y &+ &z &- &2t &= &-1 \\
  &   &      &     &z &- &t &= &0
\end{cases}$$
answer1: The system has $\left(5,\,1,\,3,\,3\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer3: The system has $\left(5+20y,\,y,\,-10-13y,\,8+15y\right)$ as solution for every $y\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer4: The system has $\left(5,0,-10,8\right)$ as its unique solution.

question:
Find the solutions of the following linear system:
$$\begin{cases}
2x & + & y & - & 4z & = & 2 \\ 
-x & + & y & + & z & = & 1 \\ 
x & + & 5y & - & 5z & = & -1
\end{cases}$$
answer2: The system has $\left(1,\,0,\,-1\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer3: The system has $\left(\frac{1}{3}+\frac{5}{3}z,\,\frac{4}{3}+\frac{2}{3}z,\,z\right)$ as solution for every $z\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer4: The system has two solutions: $\left(1,\,0,\,-1\right)$ and $\left(0,\,2,\,-1\right)$.

question:
Consider the linear applications 

$\begin{array}{cccc}
F: & \mathbb{R}^3 & \rightarrow  & \mathbb{R}^2 \\
  & (x, y, z) & \longrightarrow & (y, x-z)
\end{array}$
$\begin{array}{cccc}
G: & \mathbb{R}^2 & \rightarrow  & \mathbb{R}^2 \\
  & (x, y) & \longrightarrow & (x+y, x-2y)
\end{array}$

Choose the right answer:
answer1: $(G\circ F)(x, y, z)=(x+y-z, -2x+y+2z)$ and $(F\circ G)$ does not exist
answer2: $(F\circ G)(x, y, z)=(x+y-z, -2x+y+2z)$and $(G\circ F)$ does not exist
answer3: $(G\circ F)(x, y, z)=(F\circ G)(x, y, z)=(x+y-z, -2x+y+2z)$
answer4: $(G\circ F)(y, x-z)=(x+y-z, -2x+y+2z)$ and $(F\circ G)(x, y)=(x+y, x-2y)$

How many solutions does the following linear system have?
$$\begin{cases}
x & - & y & + & z & - & 2t & = & 0 \\
-x & - & 5y & + & z & - & 8t & = & 0 \\
2x & + & y & + & z & + & t & = & 0 \\
2x & - & 5y & + & 3z & - & 9t & = & 0
\end{cases}$$
answer1: The system has infinitely many solutions depending on two parameters.
answer2: The system has infinitely many solutions depending on one parameter.
answer4: The system has a unique solution.

A consulting firm will carry out two types of projects ($A$ and $B$). The development cost per project $A$ and $B$ is, respectively, $1$ and $2$ monetary units. The requirements in terms of analysts, programmers and terminals for each type of project are indicated in the following table:

\[
\begin{array}{|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
\text{Project} & \text{N. of programmers}  & \text{N. of analysts}  & \text{N. of terminals} \\
\hline
\text{A} & 2 & 2 & 3 \\
\text{B} & 3 & 6 & 1 \\
\hline
\end{array}
\]	

The company wants to minimize the cost of developing projects in the next period. In the development of these projects, at least $10$ programmers and $5$ analysts should be used while the company only has $6$ terminals available. How does the Linear Programming (LP) model should be formalized  to allow planning the company's activity?

The WorldLight Company produces two light fixtures (products $1$ and $2$) that require both metal frame parts and electrical components. Management wants to determine how many units of each product to produce so as to maximize profit. For each unit of product $1$, $1$ unit of frame parts and $2$ units of electrical components are required. For each unit of product $2$, $3$ units of frame parts and $2$ units of electrical components are required. The company has $200$ units of frame parts and $300$ units of electrical components. 

Each unit of product $1$ gives a profit of $1?$, and each unit of product $2$, up to $60$ units, gives a profit of $2?$. Any excess over	$60$ units of product $2$ brings no profit, so such excess has been ruled out.

How does the Linear Programming (LP) model should be formalized to allow planning of the company's activity?
answer1:
\[
\begin{array}{ll}
		\text{Maximize} & Z= x_{1} + 2x_{2}\\
		\text{subject to} & x_{1}+3x_{2}\leq 200\\
	        & 2x_{1}+2x_{2}\leq 300\\
			& x_{2}\leq 60\\
			&  x_{1},x_{2}\geq 0\\
\end{array}
\]
answer3:
\[\begin{array}{ll}
		\text{Minimize} & Z= x_{1} + 2x_{2}\\
			\text{subject to} & x_{1}+3x_{2}\leq 200\\
			    & 2x_{1}+2x_{2}\leq 300\\
			    & x_{2}\leq 60\\
			    & x_{1},x_{2}\geq 0\\
\end{array}
\]
answer4:
\[\begin{array}{ll}
		\text{Maximize} & Z= x_{1} + 2x_{2}\\
			\text{subject to} &  x_{1}+3x_{2}\leq 200\\
    			& 2x_{1}+2x_{2}\leq 300\\
			    & x_{2}\geq 60\\
			    & x_{1},x_{2}\geq 0\\
\end{array}
\]

answer1: The lines $r$ and $s$ are equal if $m=-2$, parallel if $m=2$, and secant otherwise.
